title: Gap Filling of Advanced Technology Microwave Sounder Data as Applied to Hurricane Warm Core Animations
summary: This paper presents a new methodology for gap-filling ATMS SDR brightness temperature data using the DCT-PLS smoothing algorithm, which is essential for monitoring hurricane warm core structures. The authors develop three regression-based retrieval algorithms to produce vertical atmospheric temperature fields under all weather conditions, and create a 3-D image animation system showing atmospheric temperature anomaly distribution of hurricane warm core structures.
methodology: The DCT-PLS smoothing algorithm is used to fill gaps in ATMS SDR data, which are then used as input for the regression-based retrieval algorithms. The algorithms use gap-filled ATMS SDR data from Channel 5 through Channel 12 to produce vertical atmospheric temperature fields.
statistics: Penalized Least Square Discrete Cosine Transform
research_outcomes: The authors demonstrate that their methodology can accurately fill gaps in ATMS SDR data and provide high-quality atmospheric temperature fields. The 3-D image animation system shows the effectiveness of the methodology in visualizing hurricane warm core structures.

title: Unprecedented differences in phytoplankton community structures in the Amundsen Sea Polynyas, West Antarctica
summary: This paper investigates the phytoplankton community structure in the Amundsen Sea Polynyas, West Antarctica, and finds unprecedented differences between adjacent polynyas. The study uses automated continuous observation instruments to measure phytoplankton species abundance, but does not employ machine learning or AI methods.
methodology: The study used a combination of automated continuous observation instruments and discrete water samples to measure phytoplankton species abundance and nutrient concentrations. Phytoplankton were identified using epifluorescence microscopy and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC).
research_outcomes: The study found unprecedented differences in phytoplankton community structures between adjacent polynyas, with Dactyliosolen tenuijunctus dominating the Pine Island Bay region. The results suggest that changes in ice melting conditions may influence phytoplankton distribution and composition.

title: Energy-aware and Bandwidth Allocation for Air Pollution Monitoring System using Data Analytics
summary: This paper proposes a novel framework for air pollution monitoring using wireless sensor networks, leveraging data analytics to improve the accuracy and efficiency of pollutant detection. While machine learning is mentioned as part of the methodology, its role appears minimal in this context.
methodology: The proposed research technique uses a bandwidth allocation aware Air pollution monitoring system with cuckoo and fish swarm approach to effectively monitor air pollutant values using sensors equipped in various locations.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a novel framework for air pollution monitoring, which can help assess the severity of air contamination on a daily basis, predict interactions between pollutants, and validate computer models. The results can be used to inform policy decisions and improve public awareness about air quality.

title: Forest Fires Detection using Deep Transfer Learning
summary: This paper presents a deep transfer learning approach for forest fire detection, utilizing pre-trained computer vision architectures to achieve a detection rate of over 99.9%. The methodology integrates deep learning with traditional image processing methods to identify wildfires earlier.
methodology: The proposed approach uses transfer learning from pre-trained computer vision architectures, including Xception, Dense-Net, MobileNet, and NASNetMobile, to detect forest fires. The methodology combines deep learning with traditional image processing methods.
research_outcomes: The study achieved a detection rate of over 99.9% using the proposed approach.

title: Deep Learning Based Thermal Image Processing Approach for Detection of Buried Objects and Mines
summary: This paper presents a deep learning based thermal imaging approach for the detection of buried objects and surface mines. The proposed method uses a Region Convolution Neural Network (RCNN) to identify buried objects in thermal images, achieving 90% accuracy in predicting target locations.
methodology: The proposed approach involves training a neural network using an image dataset of buried objects at known locations. The steps involved include thermal image acquisition and augmentation, gray-scale conversion and thresholding, selection of region of interest for detection, development of RCNN, and training, testing, and validation.
research_outcomes: The proposed method achieved 90% accuracy in predicting target locations of buried objects. The results show that the thermal imaging approach can be effective in detecting buried mines.
sources_of_inspiration: Other relevant works mentioned in the paper

title: Applying Machine Learning for Firebrand Production Prediction
summary: This paper presents a machine learning-based metamodeling framework for firebrand production prediction, which can provide high accuracy fire modeling in real-time. The framework uses non-linear non-parametric ML models to predict the firebrand areal mass density and number density of landing firebrands.
methodology: The metamodeling framework was implemented using a large set of data from full-scale laboratory firebrand production experiments, with independent variables including landing distance, wind speed, and fuel type.
research_outcomes: The KNN model predicted discrete FAND and FAMD values with an accuracy higher than 90%.

title: Citrus orchards under formation evaluated by UAV-Based RGB Imagery
summary: This study evaluates the use of aerial UAV images with automated routines to estimate biometric attributes of citrus orchards under formation. The method uses RGB sensors and achieves high accuracy in estimating crown projection area and plant height, making it a substantial contribution to the field.
methodology: The study uses a multirotor UAV programmed to capture images at three different map scales with a frontal and side overlap of 80%. Geoprocessing is carried out both with and without ground control points on each scale. An automated routine is developed in an opensource environment, consisting of three processing phases: i) Estimation of plant biometric attributes, ii) Statistical analysis, and iii) Statistical Report Map (SRM).
statistics: Statistical methods used include zonal statistics, arithmetic mean, and Delaunay algorithm.
research_outcomes: The study achieves high accuracy in estimating crown projection area and plant height using aerial UAV images with automated routines. The method can be easily adapted to other applications.

title: Understanding Adverse Biological Effect Predictions Using Knowledge Graphs
summary: This paper presents a novel approach for extrapolating adverse biological effects of chemicals using knowledge graphs and their vector embeddings. The method improves prediction performance by up to 40% in terms of R^2 coefficient of determination, providing quantitative and qualitative insights into the predictions.
methodology: The authors use a stressor-effect informed knowledge graph (KG) and its vector embeddings to provide additional information to the extrapolation models. They integrate key data concerning chemicals and species, and apply KGE models such as DistMult and TransE to extract low-dimensional vector representations of entities.
research_outcomes: The results show that using knowledge graph embeddings in the gap-filling prediction task can improve both the results and the interpretation of a complex model. The method provides quantitative and qualitative insights into the predictions, increasing confidence in effect prediction.

title: Walking in a heterogeneous landscape: Dispersal, gene flow and conservation implications for the giant panda in the Qinling Mountains
summary: This paper investigates the genetic status of the Qinling giant panda population, examining the factors that underpin the structuring of genetic variation within populations. The study uses a landscape genetics approach to identify the role of isolation-by-barriers (IBB), isolation-by-distance (IBD) and isolation-by-resistance (IBR) in shaping the pattern of genetic variation in this giant panda population.
methodology: landscape genetics, microsatellite data set, complementary analysis methods
research_outcomes: The Qinling population comprises one continuous genetic cluster, and gene flow was found to be correlated with resistance gradients for two topographic factors, slope aspect and topographic complexity.

title: Geant4-based simulations of charge collection in CMOS Active Pixel Sensors
summary: This paper presents Geant4-based simulations of charge collection in CMOS Active Pixel Sensors, focusing on the development of a charge transport model for accurate Monte Carlo simulations. The model includes charge generation, diffusion, and sharing across adjacent pixels, as well as the full electronic chain for a CMOS APS.
methodology: The paper uses Geant4 toolkit for simulation, with custom classes added to reproduce detector response. Energy deposition in sensitive volume is scored using standard Geant4 libraries, and individual proton interactions are approximated with a 100-nm step size.
research_outcomes: A charge transport model has been developed, validated against experimental data acquired with protons in an energy range relevant for pCT. The model includes charge generation, diffusion, collection, and sharing across adjacent pixels.

title: Cloud Detection by Luminance and Inter-band Parallax Analysis for Pushbroom Satellite Imagers
summary: This paper proposes a cloud detection algorithm for Earth observation images obtained by pushbroom satellite imagers, exploiting the inter-band disparity to detect clouds. The method is shown to be effective in detecting clouds with a balanced accuracy rate close to 98%.
methodology: The proposed algorithm is based on the analysis of parallax effects observed between the three color bands and uses an optical flow method for subpixel precision disparity map computation.
research_outcomes: The paper demonstrates a balanced accuracy rate close to 98% for cloud and non-cloud classification for Sentinel-2 images, showing the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Age-Dependent Dispersal and Relatedness in Tiger Sharks (Galeocerdo cuvier)
summary: This paper investigates the dispersal patterns of tiger sharks, focusing on the relationship between physical and reproductive dispersal. The authors use genetic data to examine fine-scale structure in populations, finding evidence of male-biased dispersal and female philopatry. However, tracking studies have shown that both males and females move similar distances, exhibiting repeated site fidelity.
methodology: The authors used a suite of microsatellite loci and DNA samples from previously-tagged tiger sharks to evaluate reproductive dispersal in light of demographic and published tracking data.
research_outcomes: The study found that lumping size classes together resulted in genetic panmixia across sites, but systematic removal of large individuals showed significant population-level differentiation and three separate population clusters among juveniles less than 260 cm total length. Tests for relatedness found that 8.9% of the sample set was composed of first-order related pairs.

title: Remote Aircraft Target Recognition Method Based on Superpixel Segmentation and Image Reconstruction
summary: This paper proposes a remote aircraft target recognition method based on superpixel segmentation and image reconstruction. The method uses histograms of oriented gradients to estimate the orientation of an aircraft, followed by improved SLIC superpixel segmentation algorithm to segment the target from complex backgrounds and shadow areas. The approach is robust to noise and recognizes targets more accurately than other methods.
methodology: The methodology involves estimating the orientation of an aircraft using histograms of oriented gradients, followed by improved SLIC superpixel segmentation algorithm to segment the target.
research_outcomes: The proposed method recognizes targets more accurately than other methods and is robust to noise.

title: Multi$^{	ext{3}}$Net: Segmenting Flooded Buildings via Fusion of Multiresolution, Multisensor, and Multitemporal Satellite Imagery
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach for rapid segmentation of flooded buildings by fusing multiresolution, multisensor, and multitemporal satellite imagery in a convolutional neural network. The model significantly expedites the generation of satellite imagery-based flood maps, crucial for first responders and local authorities in the early stages of flood events.
methodology: The network consists of multiple streams of encoder-decoder architectures that extract spatiotemporal information from medium-resolution images and spatial information from high-resolution images before fusing the resulting representations into a single medium-resolution segmentation map of flooded buildings.
research_outcomes: The model performs best on both tasks of building footprint segmentation as well as for the segmentation of flooded buildings. It produces highly accurate segmentation maps of flooded buildings using only publicly available medium-resolution data instead of significantly more detailed but sparsely available very high-resolution data.

title: Forecasting Hydropower Generation in Ghana Using ARIMA Models
summary: This paper uses the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model to forecast hydropower generation and water level of the Akosombo dam in Ghana. The study focuses on the importance of accurate forecasting for sustainable electricity supply, particularly in developing countries like Ghana.
methodology: The Box-Jenkins strategy was used to identify the ARIMA model parameters. The ACF and PACF plots were analyzed to determine the order of the autoregressive (AR) component p and the moving average (MA) component q.
statistics: Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Percentage error (MAPE) were used to evaluate the forecasting accuracy of the selected model.
research_outcomes: The study found that the ARIMA model can accurately forecast hydropower generation and water level of the Akosombo dam. The results suggest that the Volta River Authority and managers of the electricity company in Ghana may find this study useful for planning sustainable electricity supply.

title: Support vector machine tropical wind speed retrieval in the presence of rain for Ku-band wind scatterometry
summary: This paper explores the application of support vector machines (SVM) to improve wind speed retrieval during rain for tropical regions. The authors apply SVM in machine learning to solve this complex problem, leveraging data-oriented regression and triple collocation to demonstrate better similarity between resolved Ku-band winds and collocated C-band winds.
methodology: The authors use a combination of MLE and Joss indicators to segregate wind variability and rain effects in Ku-band retrievals, applying SVM with knowledge of the underlying principles to derive complexly associated wind and rain information.
research_outcomes: The results demonstrate that SVM can correct rain-contaminated winds with Ku-band winds and their QC indicators alone, achieving a minimum mean difference of -0.12 m/s at about 8 m/s and a largest difference of -3.25 m/s at about 14 m/s ASCAT speed.

title: MULTIRESOLUTION SEGMENTATION FOR EXTRACTING PLASTIC GREENHOUSES FROM DEIMOS-2 IMAGERY
summary: This paper presents a multi-resolution segmentation approach for extracting plastic greenhouses from Deimos-2 imagery. The authors use object-based image analysis (OBIA) techniques to segment the images and assess the quality of the segmentations using the AssesSeg tool.
methodology: The authors used a bottom-up region-merging technique, multi-resolution segmentation (MRS), implemented in Trimble eCognition Developer v. 9.5. They also used the AssesSeg tool to evaluate the quality of the segmentations.
research_outcomes: The authors found that the best segmentation results were obtained using the atmospherically corrected pansharpened Deimos-2 orthoimage, achieving very good results.

title: Reducing pollutant emissions from vessel maneuvering in port areas
summary: This paper proposes an activity-based model to calculate ships' exhaust emissions while maneuvering in port, and evaluates the effectiveness of green port policies. The study finds that lower speeds and onshore power supply can reduce local air pollution, and assist transportation authorities to proactively respond to the International Maritime Organization's regulations for ensuring a sustainable future.
methodology: The authors apply an activity-based model to evaluate the performance of ports in Taiwan from 2011 to 2020 and their green harbor policies.
research_outcomes: The study finds that lower speeds and onshore power supply can reduce local air pollution, and assist transportation authorities to proactively respond to the International Maritime Organization's regulations for ensuring a sustainable future.
sources_of_inspiration: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNC-TAD) 2019

title: Palaeo-tsunami inundation distances deduced from roundness of gravel particles in tsunami deposits
summary: This paper presents a new approach to estimate tsunami inundation distance based on the mixture ratio of gravels from several sources in tsunami deposits. The method uses roundness measurements and mixture ratios to identify an abrupt change in the mixture ratio at a constant percentile, regardless of tsunami magnitude. This relationship allows for the estimation of palaeo-tsunami run-up height and/or inundation area.
methodology: The study used image analysis to measure the roundness values of gravel particles in beach sediments and fluvial sediments, and then calculated the mixture ratios of these materials. The authors analyzed 164 tsunami deposit samples taken from 56 sites along a line orthogonal to the coast.
research_outcomes: The main finding is that the mixture ratios of source materials in tsunami deposits abruptly change at the same inundation distance percentile, regardless of tsunami magnitude. This allows for the estimation of palaeo-tsunami run-up height and/or inundation area.

title: TermPicks: A century of Greenland glacier terminus data for use in machine learning applications
summary: This paper presents a comprehensive dataset of manually digitized glacier termini for Greenland's outlet glaciers, which will be used as training data for machine learning methods. The dataset includes 39,060 individual terminus traces for 278 glaciers and has been cleaned and reformatted for use in scientific analysis.
methodology: The authors collected terminus traces through email requests to authors who had published papers that made use of such data or from publicly available online databases. The data were then re-projected into NSIDC Sea Ice Polar Stereographic North (EPSG:3413) and exported into a single ESRI line shapefile format.
research_outcomes: The dataset provides a comprehensive understanding of glacier termini for Greenland's outlet glaciers, which will aid in the interpretation of glacier dynamics in response to climate variability. The authors also highlight the need for coordinated data management and the potential for machine learning methods to automate accurate extraction of glacier termini.

title: Study on the Dust Content in Dead-End Drifts in the Potash Mines for Various Ventilation Modes
summary: This paper investigates dust content reduction in potash mines using various ventilation modes. The study focuses on the dynamics of a dust-air mixture and proposes a mathematical model for numerical simulation, but does not involve machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The Euler-Euler approach and the model of a homogeneous multicomponent medium are used to simulate the dust-air mixture dynamics. Experimental studies were carried out in three cases: forced ventilation systems with different distances between the end of the ventilation duct and the combine driver's cab, and an exhaust ventilation system.
research_outcomes: The study concludes that the most effective parameters of ventilation systems can minimize dust concentration in dead-end drifts. The results provide a basis for optimizing ventilation modes to reduce occupational diseases among miners.

title: Focusing on Shadows for Predicting Heightmaps from Single Remotely Sensed RGB Images with Deep Learning
summary: This paper proposes a deep learning model that uses shadows in remotely sensed images to predict heightmaps. The model takes advantage of the shadow map, which is calculated efficiently using image operators, and achieves superior performance on the task.
methodology: The proposed DL model receives a single aerial image and a binary map of its shadows as input, and predicts its heightmap. The shadows map is inserted as an extra information channel to the image, alongside the colour channels.
research_outcomes: The model achieves superior performance on the task of predicting heightmaps from single remotely sensed images, outperforming other methods that require expensive and precise data preprocessing.

title: Bayesian network modelling provides spatial and temporal understanding of ecosystem dynamics within shallow shelf seas
summary: This paper uses Bayesian networks to model the complex interactions between physical and biological variables in shallow shelf seas, providing a data-driven understanding of ecosystem dynamics. The study focuses on four contrasting regions in the North Sea, examining changes over 30 years and identifying key indicators of abundance or biomass change.
methodology: The authors used a machine learning optimization technique to find data-driven estimates of interactions among physical and biological variables, incorporating a hidden variable to model non-stationary dynamics.
research_outcomes: The study identified key indicators of abundance or biomass change, including physical (e.g. bottom temperature, potential energy anomaly) and biological variables (e.g. sandeel larvae, net primary production). The results highlight the importance of considering non-stationary dynamics in ecological analyses.

title: Ecosystem Respiration and Gross Primary Productivity in a Subalpine Grassland
summary: This paper investigates ecosystem respiration and gross primary productivity in a subalpine grassland, but does not utilize machine learning or AI methods. The study focuses on the effects of warming and altered water availability on plant performance and carbon budget.
methodology: The authors used a combination of field measurements and modeling to estimate ecosystem respiration and gross primary productivity. They measured net ecosystem exchange (NEE) using a static cuvette and infrared CO2 probe, and parameterized light response curves for GPP.
research_outcomes: The study found that warming and altered water availability had significant effects on plant performance and carbon budget. However, the results of the irrigation treatment were inconclusive due to a lack of explicit evidence of drought.

title: Assessment of Habitat Change Processes within the Oti-Keran-Mandouri Network of Protected Areas in Togo (West Africa) from 1987 to 2013 Using Decision Tree Analysis
summary: This paper assesses habitat change processes within the Oti-Keran-Mandouri complex of protected areas in Togo using decision tree analysis. The study uses satellite-derived land cover maps to identify habitat change processes and their impact on biodiversity conservation.
methodology: Decision Tree Analysis
research_outcomes: The study identifies habitat loss, fragmentation, and degradation as major threats to biodiversity in the Oti-Keran-Mandouri complex. The results highlight the importance of understanding habitat change processes for effective conservation planning.
